text: I'm automotive journalist Lindsay Brook
and we're here at the Greenfield Village
at the Henry Ford Museum Complex in
Dearborn Michigan and this is very close
to where Henry Ford really started his
enterprise the neat thing about
Greenfield Village is it operates the
world's biggest fleet of operating Model
T Fords fifteen cars at any given day
are circulating around the village
hauling passengers hauling cargo and
performing in many ways like they did
100 years ago this September the Model T
celebrates its centennial anniversary
100 years since the car was first
introduced by Henry Ford perhaps the
greatest physical distinction of the
Model T Ford versus cars of today is its
crank starting system the driver had to
set the throttle opening he had to set
the spark advance had to move around and
pull a choke out and then actually crank
start the car with a lever and make sure
that he didn't wrap his thumb around the
starter lever or he could possibly break
his thumb in today's cars you get in the
car sometimes you just push a button to
start the car and it starts it starts in
any weather it was very different back
in the Model T's day
perhaps the most fantastic part of the
Model T legend was how Henry Ford
slashed the price of his car so
everybody could afford it he really
wanted working people farmers the
everyday person to be able to afford
this car even the people that work in
his own plants and so from late 1908
when the car was introduced it cost
about eight hundred and fifty dollars by
the early 1920s the price had been
slashed almost 70 percent to two hundred
and sixty dollars what a value this is
why during that period virtually half of
the cars on the road worldwide were
Model T Fords the Model T Ford was
lightyears ahead of every car of its
period when it was introduced in 1908
and during its nineteen year production
run it really revolutionized the way
automobiles were designed built and sold
to the customer as well
it was really the car that put the world
on wheels bringing people from rural
areas finally into metropolitan areas
and making mass transportation on a
personal level available to everybody
